titlestmt.titleproper: Mary C. Davidow collection of research materials on Charlotte Mew 1928-1975
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: Mary C. Davidow collection of research materials on Charlotte Mew

bioghist.p: Charlotte Mary Mew was an English poet (1869-1928). Although her life was lived for the most part in poverty and despair she was still recognized by Vita Sackville West as a poetess of distinction. Virginia Woolf called her the greatest living poetess, and Marianne Moore, a quarter of a century after her death, considered her work "above praise." Mary Davidow studied at Brown University and is a professor of English at William Patterson College. Her study of Mew was originally undertaken for her Ph.D., which she received in 1960.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers and correspondence relating to a proposed work on Mew by Mary C.Davidow. Correspondents include Alida Monro, T.S. Eliot, Siegfried Sasson, Rebecca West, and Sydney Cockerell. Also included are photocopies of letters written by Mew, typed transcripts of letters to Mew, photographs and negatives, and notebooks and pocket diaries kept by Davidow.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: A paper finding aid is available in the repository.
